deliberation: I checked the imperatives and place names (Benjamin, Jerusalem, Tekoa, Beth‑haccerem) as literal military alarm instructions. The clause ‘evil is appearing from the north, and great shever (breaking)’ uses abstract ‘evil’ and ‘breaking’ for a concrete invading force and calamity, with ‘evil’ portrayed as something that appears/overlooks from the north. I treat these as two related but distinct figurative expressions.

instances.english_text: For evil is appearing from the north
vehicle: ‘evil’ as a thing that appears/overlooks from a direction
instances.explanation: The coming northern invaders are compressed into the abstract ‘evil’ which is described as ‘appearing/overlooking’ from the north, personifying the calamity as a looming presence on the horizon.

instances.english_text: and great disaster (lit. ‘a great breaking’)
instances.explanation: The term ‘shever’ (breaking/fracture) is used metaphorically for large‑scale communal disaster, picturing Judah’s fate as something violently broken.

deliberation: I examined whether the verse is purely descriptive or figurative. ‘Daughter of Zion’ plus adjectives ‘fair, delicate’ frame Jerusalem as a pampered woman/daughter. This is a conventional personification/metaphor for the city and its inhabitants, not a literal individual.

instances.english_text: Fair Zion, the lovely and delicate, I have likened the daughter of Zion
ground: beauty, privilege, protected status, vulnerability to ruin
posture: reproach of a pampered yet judged community
instances.explanation: ‘Daughter of Zion’ personifies the city as a pampered, delicate young woman whom God has ‘likened’ in order to announce her impending ruin.

deliberation: I considered whether actual shepherds are in view or whether this is standard Near Eastern imagery for rulers/armies. Given the siege context (tents pitched around her) and parallel war language, ‘shepherds and their flocks’ depict enemy leaders and their troops in pastoral imagery.

instances.english_text: Against her come shepherds with their flocks
ground: leaders surrounded by dependents, encircling and ‘grazing’ a territory
control and organization of a group
posture: depiction of siege using pastoral imagery
instances.explanation: Foreign leaders and their armies are metaphorically presented as ‘shepherds’ encamping with their ‘flocks’ around Jerusalem, transferring pastoral imagery into a martial setting.

deliberation: The verse is largely direct military speech (‘sanctify war’, ‘let us go up at noon’). The clauses ‘day is declining, the shadows of evening are stretched’ fit a literal time‑of‑day description in battle planning rather than symbolizing something else. I do not see a distinct figurative expression beyond normal descriptive language.

The text continues direct military commands about attacking at night and destroying fortresses. These are straightforward war instructions without an apparent transfer from one conceptual domain to another, so I do not classify any part as figurative language.

I evaluated ‘hew trees’ and ‘pour out a siege ramp’ as literal siege tactics. Calling Jerusalem ‘the city visited/punished’ and saying ‘oppression is in her midst’ are standard prophetic descriptions; ‘in her midst’ refers straightforwardly to the population. No clear metaphor, simile, or other figure beyond normal abstraction is present.

The opening uses an explicit comparative construction ‘as … so …’, likening a well/cistern producing water to Jerusalem’s production of evil. The following phrases about ‘violence and spoil are heard’ and ‘before Me continually sickness and wound’ describe moral and physical conditions without a fresh vehicle, so I isolate the well/water image as the main figure.

instances.english_text: As a well flows with its water, so she flows with her wickedness
vehicle: a well/cistern that continually brings forth water
ground: naturalness and abundance of what issues forth
instances.explanation: Jerusalem’s evil is compared to a well that continually brings up water, highlighting how naturally and constantly wickedness issues from within the city.

deliberation: Most language is direct (‘accept discipline’, ‘lest I make you a desolation’). The clause ‘lest My soul be torn/alienated from you’ uses the term ‘soul’ (נפש) of YHWH and the verb ‘be torn out/alienated’, which anthropomorphically pictures God as a person whose inner self recoils. I count that as figurative, while the desolation imagery is consistent with literal devastation.

instances.english_text: lest My soul be torn/alienated from you
vehicle: a human ‘soul’ recoiling and being torn away
inner self of a person withdrawing in disgust
instances.explanation: God’s covenant favor is portrayed as a human ‘soul’ that might be torn away in revulsion, personifying and anthropomorphizing the divine reaction to Jerusalem’s behavior.

deliberation: The verse twice compares treatment of Israel’s remnant to viticultural practices (‘glean as a vine’, ‘like a vintager over the branches’). Both similes support one coherent metaphorical picture: Israel as a vineyard stripped through repeated gleaning, representing thorough judgment.

instances.hebrew_text: עוֹלֵ֛ל יְעוֹלְל֥וּ כַגֶּ֖פֶן שְׁאֵרִ֣ית יִשְׂרָאֵ֑ל הָשֵׁב֙ יָֽדְךָ֔ כְּבוֹצֵ֖ר עַל־סַלְסִלּֽוֹת
instances.english_text: They shall glean, glean as a vine the remnant of Israel; pass your hand again, like a vintager, over its branches
target: the remnant of Israel under repeated judgment
vehicle: a vine being repeatedly gleaned by a grape‑harvester
instances.explanation: Israel’s remnant is likened to a vine repeatedly gleaned by a harvester, conveying how judgment will go over them again and again until little remains.

deliberation: I noted the question about whom to warn as literal, and focused on the characterization ‘their ears are uncircumcised’, a stock prophetic metaphor for spiritual insensitivity. The rest (‘word of YHWH is a reproach’) functions as direct evaluation, not as a new image.

instances.english_text: See, their ears are uncircumcised
target: the people’s inability/unwillingness to heed God
instances.explanation: The people’s refusal to listen is pictured as ‘uncircumcised ears’, transferring the imagery of uncircumcised flesh to their faculty of hearing to express spiritual insensitivity.

deliberation: The capture of various age groups is literal judgment language. The opening, however, describes Jeremiah as ‘filled’ with YHWH’s wrath and then uses the verb ‘pour it out’ on people, conceptualizing wrath as a liquid in a vessel that can be stored and poured. I treat this as a metaphor for the manifestation of divine anger through prophecy and judgment.

instances.hebrew_text: וְאֵת֩ חֲמַ֨ת יְהוָה מָלֵאתִי נִלְאֵיתִי הָכִיל שְׁפֹךְ עַל־עוֹלָל
instances.english_text: I am filled with the wrath of the LORD; I am weary of holding it in. Pour it out upon the infants…
target: the experience and execution of divine anger through Jeremiah
vehicle: a container filled with liquid that is hard to hold in and can be poured out
ground: intensity, overflow, and externalization of inner anger
posture: expression of constrained but impending judgment
instances.explanation: YHWH’s wrath is depicted as a liquid filling Jeremiah to the brim that he can scarcely contain and must ‘pour out’ on the people, figuratively conveying the pressure and release of judgment.

deliberation: Loss of houses, fields, and wives reads as literal consequences of invasion. The phrase ‘I will stretch out My hand against the inhabitants of the land’ is a recurrent anthropomorphic metaphor for God’s active intervention; God does not literally have a physical arm extended in space.

instances.english_text: For I will stretch out My hand against the inhabitants of the land
target: God’s exercise of power in judgment on the population
vehicle: a human hand/arm being stretched out in hostile action
ground: decisive, directed intervention; ability to strike and control
instances.explanation: YHWH depicts His coming judgment as ‘stretching out His hand’, an anthropomorphic metaphor likening divine action to a human’s reaching out to strike.

deliberation: The greed and falsity of all social levels are described. The phrase ‘from the smallest to the greatest’ is a merism, using extremes to represent totality. I focus on that as the principal figure; the rest is literal ethical accusation.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּ֤י מִקְּטַנָּם֙ וְעַד־גְּדוֹלָ֔ם כֻּלּ֖וֹ בּוֹצֵ֣עַ בָּ֑צַע
instances.english_text: For from the smallest of them to the greatest of them, all are greedy for gain
target: the entire social spectrum of Judah
vehicle: ‘smallest’ and ‘greatest’ as endpoints of a scale
instances.explanation: The expression ‘from the smallest to the greatest’ is a merism, using opposite social extremes to express that everyone in between shares the same greedy behavior.

deliberation: The verse presents ‘the fracture/wound of My people’ and ‘healing lightly’—medical language applied to national/spiritual crisis. ‘Peace, peace, and there is no peace’ functions as the content of their false reassurance and carries an ironic force but is still within the medical frame. I treat the medical imagery as one central metaphor.

instances.hebrew_text: וַֽיְרַפְּא֞וּ אֶת־שֶׁ֤בֶר עַמִּי֙ עַל־נְקַלָּ֔ה לֵאמֹ֖ר שָׁלוֹם שָׁלוֹם וְאֵין שָׁלוֹם
instances.english_text: They have healed the fracture of My people lightly, saying, ‘Peace, peace,’ when there is no peace
target: the deep moral and political crisis of Israel
vehicle: a physical fracture/wound superficially treated by a healer
ground: serious underlying damage masked by superficial treatment
false reassurance instead of real remedy
posture: exposure of false assurances as shallow treatment
instances.explanation: The nation’s grave condition is depicted as a bodily ‘fracture’ that corrupt leaders ‘heal’ in a trivial way by proclaiming peace, an image that also carries irony since there is actually no peace.

deliberation: The discourse on shame is literal moral evaluation. The clauses ‘they shall fall among the falling; at the time I punish them they shall stumble’ use physical falling and stumbling as a standard metaphor for moral and existential downfall under judgment.

instances.english_text: Therefore they shall fall among the falling; at the time that I punish them, they shall stumble
instances.explanation: The coming judgment is described in terms of physical falling and stumbling, metaphorically portraying the people’s spiritual and social collapse.

deliberation: The verse uses ‘roads’, ‘paths’, and ‘the good way’ with commands to ‘walk in it’ and find ‘rest for your souls’. In context these do not refer to literal roads but to ways of life and covenantal obedience, a sustained metaphor of moral choice as travel on a path.

instances.hebrew_text: עִמְדוּ עַל־דְּרָכִים ... וּשַׁאֲלוּ לִנְתִבוֹת עוֹלָם אֵי־זֶה דֶרֶךְ הַטּוֹב וּלְכוּ־בָהּ וּמִצְאוּ מַרְגּוֹעַ לְנַפְשְׁכֶם
instances.english_text: Stand by the roads and see, and ask for the ancient paths, ‘Where is the good way?’ and walk in it, and find rest for your souls
vehicle: roads, ancient paths, and a ‘good way’ one can walk
travel routes and choices of direction
ground: choosing between alternatives, long‑established routes, and destinations
consequences of the chosen course (rest vs. unrest)
posture: appeal to return to traditional obedience
instances.explanation: Covenantal obedience is portrayed as choosing and walking on an ‘ancient’ good road, promising rest, while the people refuse to take that path.

deliberation: I distinguished between two overlapping images: prophets as ‘watchmen’ over the people, and the ‘sound of the shofar’ as a warning to heed. The first is a metaphor of prophetic vigilance; the second uses a military alarm horn as a metonym for the prophetic warning message itself.

instances.english_text: And I raised up watchmen over you
vehicle: military watchmen/lookouts stationed over a city
ground: vigilance, early warning about approaching danger
instances.explanation: Prophets are portrayed as military watchmen set over the people to warn of coming danger.

instances.english_text: Listen to the sound of the horn
vehicle: the sound of a battle horn (shofar)
ground: urgent, unmistakable call that demands response
instances.explanation: The ‘sound of the horn’ stands metonymically for the prophets’ warning message that should rouse the people like a battle alarm.

deliberation: The verse addresses ‘nations’ and a ‘congregation’ to hear and know what is coming on Israel. These are real groups being summoned as witnesses; I do not detect a transfer between conceptual domains, so I classify the language as rhetorical but not figurative in the narrow sense requested.

Two figures appear: (1) ‘Hear, O earth’ personifies the earth as a listening witness; (2) ‘the fruit of their thoughts’ uses harvest imagery for the consequences of their schemes. Both are distinct conceptual transfers.

instances.english_text: Hear, O earth!
target: all creation as witness to God’s judgment on Israel
vehicle: the earth as a hearing subject
person who can listen and bear witness
posture: formal summoning of witnesses to judgment
instances.explanation: The inanimate earth is addressed as if it could hear, personifying creation as a witness in the covenant lawsuit against the people.

instances.english_text: the fruit of their thoughts
target: the consequences/results of the people’s schemes
ground: natural outgrowth from what is sown/planted
inevitable result emerging from prior causes
instances.explanation: Their coming disaster is described as ‘the fruit of their thoughts’, likening the outcome of their schemes to a harvest that grows from what they have sown.

deliberation: The verse uses rhetorical questions about frankincense from Sheba and sweet cane as unacceptable offerings. These seem straightforward critiques of cultic practice; no distinct metaphor or simile beyond normal abstract evaluation (‘not acceptable’, ‘not pleasing’) is present.

I asked whether the ‘stumbling blocks’ are literal obstacles or figurative for calamities. Given the context of parents and children together perishing, the ‘stumbling blocks’ function as metaphorical causes of ruin—judgment events over which they will stumble.

instances.hebrew_text: הִנְנִ֥י נֹתֵ֛ן אֶל־הָעָ֥ם הַזֶּ֖ה מִכְשֹׁלִ֑ים וְכָשְׁלוּ בָם
instances.english_text: I am putting before this people stumbling blocks, over which they shall stumble
target: the people’s experience of divinely‑sent calamities
vehicle: physical obstacles in a path that cause a person to trip
ground: unexpected hindrance leading to fall and injury
inability to continue on one’s way
instances.explanation: Future calamities are pictured as ‘stumbling blocks’ placed before the people, over which they will trip and fall, conveying the disruptive and ruinous nature of the judgment.

deliberation: The coming of a people from the north and a great nation awakened from the ends of the earth reads as direct prediction. The northern orientation is a typical prophetic motif but here functions as geographic description of the invader, not as a separate metaphor.

Most details (bow, javelin, cruelty, horses) are literal martial description. Two figures stand out: (1) ‘their voice is like the sea that roars’—an explicit simile; (2) ‘against you, daughter of Zion’—the recurring personification of Jerusalem as a ‘daughter’.

instances.english_text: Their sound is like the roaring sea
target: the noise of the invading army
posture: emphasis on terrifying power of invader
instances.explanation: The sound of the army is compared to a roaring sea, highlighting its overwhelming, fearsome, and uncontrollable nature.

instances.english_text: against you, O daughter of Zion
ground: affectionate yet vulnerable status, familial relationship
emotional resonance of assault on a daughter
posture: portrayal of the city as a vulnerable person under attack
instances.explanation: Jerusalem is personified as ‘daughter Zion’, a young woman against whom the army is arrayed, intensifying the emotional force of the coming assault.

deliberation: The verse contains two clear figures: (1) ‘our hands are slack/feeble’—an idiomatic metaphor for loss of courage; (2) ‘anguish has seized us, pain like a woman in childbirth’—an explicit simile comparing terror to labor pains.

instances.english_text: our hands have become feeble
target: the people’s courage and ability to act
vehicle: loss of physical strength in the limbs
ground: inability to act decisively, paralysis, discouragement
instances.explanation: Loss of courage is expressed idiomatically as ‘our hands have become weak’, metaphorically linking emotional collapse to physical feebleness.

instances.english_text: anguish like a woman in childbirth
target: the community’s intense fear and anguish
ground: sudden, gripping, inescapable pain; physical and emotional extremity
instances.explanation: The terror that seizes the people is likened to the pains of a woman in labor, emphasizing its intensity and inescapability.

deliberation: The commands not to go out or walk on the road are literal protective advice. ‘Sword of the enemy’ functions as a metonymy for the enemy’s violent warfare in general, and ‘terror on every side’ is a stock phrase but primarily an intensified description of pervasive fear. I treat the ‘sword’ phrasing as the main figure.

instances.english_text: for the sword is for the enemy
vehicle: the enemy’s sword as a weapon
ground: capacity to kill and threaten, immediate lethal danger
instances.explanation: The ‘sword of the enemy’ stands metonymically for the enemy’s warfare and lethal presence in the countryside and on the roads.

deliberation: There are two figures: (1) ‘daughter of my people’—personifying the nation as a daughter; (2) ‘make mourning for yourself as for an only child’—a simile likening the intensity of grief to that for an only son. The sackcloth and dust are standard mourning practices, here literal ritual expressions.

instances.english_text: O daughter of my people
vehicle: a daughter belonging to a parent
ground: intimate bond, vulnerability, pathos of impending suffering
posture: tender yet urgent address to a doomed community
instances.explanation: The nation is personified as ‘daughter of my people’, a familial image that heightens the emotional tone of the call to mourning.

instances.english_text: Make mourning for yourself as for an only child
target: the grief the people are called to express
ground: extreme, heart‑rending grief; sense of irreparable loss
uniqueness and irreplaceability of what is lost
instances.explanation: The people’s mourning is to match the intensity of grief for an only child, conveying how severe the coming loss will be.

deliberation: The verse casts Jeremiah in metallurgical terms: ‘I have made you a tester among my people, a fortress, that you may know and test their way.’ The ‘tester/assayer’ image dominates; ‘fortress’ may imply his invulnerability. I treat this as one extended metaphor of Jeremiah as an assayer/refiner of metal (the people).

instances.hebrew_text: בָּח֛וֹן נְתַתִּ֥יךָ בְעַמִּ֖י מִבְצָ֑ר וְתֵדַ֕ע וּבָחַנְתָּ֖ אֶת־דַּרְכָּֽם
instances.english_text: I have made you an assayer among My people, a fortress, that you may know and assay their way
target: Jeremiah’s prophetic role toward the people
vehicle: a metal assayer/refiner working from a secure testing site/fortress
ground: testing and revealing true quality, exposing impurities
instances.explanation: Jeremiah is portrayed as an assayer of metal set among the people to test their ‘ways’, exposing their true moral quality as a refiner reveals the quality of ore.

deliberation: Beyond moral labels (‘rebellious, slanderers, corruptors’), the phrase ‘bronze and iron are they’ uses metal imagery for character—suggesting hardness and perhaps worthlessness. I treat that as a compact metaphor for their unyielding, base nature.

instances.english_text: They are all bronze and iron
ground: hardness, resistance to change, possibly lower value compared to precious metals
instances.explanation: Their character is likened to bronze and iron, stressing their hardness and resistance to refinement.

deliberation: The verse continues the metallurgical scene: bellows blowing, lead consumed by fire, the refiner refining in vain because the wicked are not removed. This imagery applies a smelting process to the people’s moral refinement. I see it as one coherent metaphor of failed refining.

instances.hebrew_text: נָחַ֣ר מַפֻּ֔חַ ... לַשָּׁוְא צָרַ֣ף צָר֔וֹף וְרָעִ֖ים לֹ֥א נִתָּֽקוּ
instances.english_text: The bellows blow; the lead is consumed by fire; in vain the smelter smelts, but the wicked are not separated out
target: the repeated but ineffective attempts to purify the people
vehicle: a metal refining process with bellows, lead, and smelter
ground: intense efforts to refine and purify, yet failure to remove impurities
heat and pressure applied without desired result
instances.explanation: The use of bellows, fire, and smelting in vain pictures God’s disciplinary and prophetic efforts as a refining process that nonetheless fails to remove the wicked, highlighting their resistance.

deliberation: This verse concludes the refining motif by explicitly naming the people ‘rejected silver’ because YHWH has rejected them. The people are identified with defective metal, completing the metaphor begun in vv. 27–29.

instances.hebrew_text: כֶּ֣סֶף נִמְאָ֔ס קָרְא֖וּ לָהֶ֑ם כִּֽי־מָאַ֥ס יְהוָ֖ה בָּהֶֽם
instances.english_text: They are called ‘rejected silver,’ for the LORD has rejected them
target: the people of Judah under divine rejection
ground: failed quality test, lack of value, subject to discard
posture: final verdict of worthlessness under judgment
instances.explanation: The people are metaphorically named ‘rejected silver’, indicating that, like silver that fails the assay and is discarded, they are rejected by God as unfit.
